{{good article}} {{infobox military unit |unit_name=No. 8 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF |image=[[File:No. 8 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF (AWM P10648.001).JPG|300px|alt=Informal portrait of uniformed man in slouch hat standing in front of sign reading "Royal Australian Air Force No. EFTS Narrandera"]] |caption=Trainee at No. 8 Elementary Flying Training School, c. 1941 |dates=1940–45 |country=Australia |branch=[[Royal Australian Air Force]] |role=Introductory flying training |size= |command_structure=[[Central Area Command (RAAF)|Central Area Command]] (1940–41)
No. 2 (Training) Group (1941–45) |garrison=[[Narrandera Airport|Narrandera]], New South Wales |garrison_label= |nickname= |motto= |battles=World War II |battles_label=Service |notable_commanders= |aircraft_trainer=[[de Havilland Tiger Moth|Tiger Moth]] }} '''No. 8 Elementary Flying Training School''' (No. 8 EFTS) was a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) pilot training unit that operated during World War II. It was one of twelve elementary flying training schools employed by the RAAF to provide introductory flight instruction to new pilots as part of Australia's contribution to the [[British Commonwealth Air Training Plan|Empire Air Training Scheme]]. No. 8 EFTS was established in September 1940 at [[Narrandera Airport|Narrandera]], New South Wales. Training ceased in December 1944 and the school was reduced to maintaining base infrastructure and aircraft. It was officially disbanded in June 1945 and renamed Care and Maintenance Unit (CMU) Narrandera. The CMU was disbanded in December 1947. ==History== Flying instruction in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) underwent major changes following the outbreak of World War II, in response to a vast increase in the number of aircrew volunteers and the commencement of Australia's participation in the [[British Commonwealth Air Training Plan|Empire Air Training Scheme]] (EATS). The Air Force's pre-war pilot training facility, [[No. 1 Flying Training School RAAF|No. 1 Flying Training School]] at [[RAAF Williams|RAAF Station Point Cook]], Victoria, was supplanted in 1940–41 by twelve elementary flying training schools (EFTS) and eight service flying training schools (SFTS).Stephens (2006), pp. 67–70[https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070724--1-.pdf Gillison (1962), p. 111] The EFTS provided a twelve-week introductory flying course to personnel who had graduated from one of the RAAF's initial training schools. Flying training was undertaken in two stages: the first involved four weeks of instruction (including ten hours of flying) to determine trainees' suitability to become pilots. Those that passed this grading process then received a further eight weeks of training (including sixty-five hours of flying) at the EFTS. Pilots who successfully completed this course were posted to an SFTS in either Australia or Canada for the next stage of their instruction as military aviators.[https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070724--1-.pdf Gillison (1962), pp. 106–109] No. 8 Elementary Flying Training School was formed at [[Narrandera Airport|Narrandera]], New South Wales, on 19 September 1940, and came under the control of [[Central Area Command (RAAF)|Central Area Command]].RAAF Historical Section (1995), pp. 27–28Ashworth (2000) pp. 33–34 The school occupied the site of the recently constructed civil airfield, as well as surrounding government land.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article144301228 |title=Air school |newspaper=[[The Daily Advertiser (Wagga Wagga)|The Daily Advertiser]] |location=Wagga Wagga |date=9 May 1940 |accessdate=6 January 2016 |page=4 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}} Its inaugural commanding officer was [[Flying Officer]] G.F. Hughes. Despite primitive accommodation and lack of infrastructure at Narrandera, the first sixty students arrived at the school on the day of its establishment. Flying training did not get completely under way until mid-November. The school's strength as at month's end was 469 staff, including thirty-six officers. Recent newspaper reports had suggested that the Narrandera base would be closed owing to "unsuitable ground" and "the direction of the prevailing wind ... allied with the surrounding terrain".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17709629 |title=Air training site unsuitable |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=8 November 1940 |accessdate=6 January 2016 |page=10 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article144329168 |title=Air training site unsuitable |newspaper=The Daily Advertiser |location=Wagga Wagga |date=9 November 1940 |accessdate=6 January 2016 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} A cyclone hit the airfield on 6 December, destroying twenty-two [[de Havilland Tiger Moth]] trainers in a matter of minutes and damaging others. The RAAF resolved to replace the wrecked aircraft as soon as possible and, the next day, the [[Minister for Air (Australia)|Minister for Air]] denied the earlier reports that the base was unsuitable and would be closed.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27949141 |title=Planes damaged in cyclone |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney|date=7 December 1940 |accessdate=6 January 2016 |page=15 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} [[File:No. 8 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF pilot 1940 (AWM 134653).JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.39|No. 8 EFTS pilot beside his training aircraft, May 1940|alt=Pilot in flying gear next to biplane]] No. 8 EFTS's first course completed on 10 December 1940; fifty students graduated.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article144325767 |title=Narandera air school |newspaper=The Daily Advertiser|location=Wagga Wagga |date=11 December 1940 |accessdate=6 January 2016 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} As of the end of the month, the school had twenty-nine instructors, 111 students under training, and forty-one serviceable aircraft.Royal Australian Air Force (1940–42) p. 310 An instructor was killed and three other men were injured when a Tiger Moth crashed while flying at low level over one of Narrandera's satellite airfields on 4 January 1941.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17727611 |title=RAAF crash |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney |date=6 January 1941 |accessdate=6 January 2016 |page=11 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/ViewImage.aspx?B=7127153|title=Tiger Moth A17-182|work=Tiger Moth A17 [Accidents Part 8] |publisher=[[National Archives of Australia]]|accessdate=6 January 2016|pages=6–7}} Two of the school's Tiger Moths collided at {{convert|3,000|feet|m}} on 8 March; the instructor and student of one plane bailed out, while the other two pilots crash-landed their aircraft, and there were no injuries.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17730591 |title=Planes collide in mid-air |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney |date=8 March 1941 |accessdate=6 January 2016 |page=14 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/ViewImage.aspx?B=7127547|title=Tiger Moth A17-169 with A17-181|work=Tiger Moth A17 [Accidents Part 23] [Collisions between aircraft] |publisher=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=6 January 2016|pages=24–25}} The school came under the control of the newly formed No. 2 (Training) Group in August, following the disbandment of Central Area Command.Ashworth (2000) p. 39Royal Australian Air Force (1940–42) pp. 302–303 As of 31 December 1941, the school had twenty-eight instructors, 123 students under training, and thirty-seven serviceable aircraft.Royal Australian Air Force (1940–42) p. 298 By 30 April 1942, the figures had risen to fifty-eight instructors, 211 students, and over seventy aircraft; strength remained at a similar level for the remainder of the year.Royal Australian Air Force (1940–42) pp. 286–293 On 8 September 1942, a No. 8 EFTS Tiger Moth dived to the ground soon after take-off from a satellite airfield and collided with a tender; one man in the tender was killed and several others, as well as both pilots, were injured.{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/ViewImage.aspx?B=7127151|title=Tiger Moth A17-125|work=Tiger Moth A17 [Accidents Part 6] |publisher=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=6 January 2016|pages=1–2}} Four pilots were killed and two Tiger Moths destroyed following a mid-air collision at {{convert|600|feet|m}} over another of Narrandera's satellite airfields on 9 March 1943.{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/ViewImage.aspx?B=7127547|title=Tiger Moth A17-174 with A17-257|work=Tiger Moth A17 [Accidents Part 23] [Collisions between aircraft] |publisher=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=6 January 2016|pages=26–28}} A pilot from the school was killed in a crash near [[Junee]] on 24 March.{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/ViewImage.aspx?B=7127152|title=Tiger Moth A17-125|work=Tiger Moth A17 [Accidents Part 7] |publisher=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=6 January 2016|pages=31–32}} Another No. 8 EFTS pilot was killed and his crewman badly injured on 17 August after their Tiger Math failed to recover from a spin.{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/ViewImage.aspx?B=7127148|title=Tiger Moth A17-68 (Jay)|work=Tiger Moth A17 [Accidents Part 3] |publisher=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=6 January 2016|pages=}} When flying training at [[No. 1 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF|No. 1 Elementary Flying Training School]], [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]], ceased in September 1944, several of the pilots still undergoing instruction were posted to No. 8 EFTS.Royal Australian Air Force (1939–45), pp. 125, 127 No. 8 EFTS received an [[Avro Anson]] the following month for use in ground instruction. Flying training was suspended in December 1944; the school was among several to be reduced to "nucleus" and continue to function primarily for the upkeep of base infrastructure and equipment under a reorganisation of EATS establishments in Australia.{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=166516|title=Formation, organisation and movement – No. 1 Flying Training School|pages=62–63|publisher=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=6 January 2016}} By this time No. 8 EFTS had eighty-three Tiger Moths on its strength. Owing to the surplus of trained aircrew in Australia, No. 8 EFTS was officially disbanded on 16 June 1945 and re-formed as Care and Maintenance Unit (CMU) Narrandera.AWM, ''Squadrons, Formations & Units of the Royal Australian Air Force and Their Deployment'', p. 19 CMU Narrandera was one of many such units that the RAAF raised for the storage and maintenance of surplus aircraft prior to their disposal after the war.Stephens (1995), pp. 12–13 It was disbanded on 5 July 1947. The No. 8 EFTS Tiger Moth Memorial was dedicated at Narrandera by retired Air Chief Marshal [[Neville McNamara|Sir Neville McNamara]] on 2 October 1988.{{cite web|url=https://www.warmemorialsregister.nsw.gov.au/content/narrandera-tiger-moth-memorial|title=Narrandera Tiger Moth Memorial|publisher=[[ New South Wales Government]]|accessdate=6 January 2015}} ==Commanding officers== No. 8 EFTS was commanded by the following officers: {|class="wikitable" |+ !
